title: Photo Deconstruction: Illuminating Yellow Fashion Shoot
summary: Photographer Lindsay Adler demonstrates a high-contrast fashion lighting setup featuring the Pantone Color of the Year, Illuminating Yellow. She details her three-light setup optimized for dark skin tones, camera settings, and a specific color grading workflow that involves desaturating skin tones to make the yellow wardrobe pop.

steps.action: Set up the main light using a Profoto XL Deep White Umbrella with diffusion on the right side to create soft, flattering light for the model's skin texture.
Place a White V-Flat on the left side to bounce fill light into the shadows, preventing the dark skin from falling into pure black.
Add two rim lights using 1x4ft Strip Softboxes with Straw Yellow gels and grids on either side of the subject to match the dress color and prevent light spill.
Use a dark gray background (Savage Universal Storm Gray) to provide contrast and flexibility for potential gelling.
Set camera exposure: 1/200 sec, f/8, ISO 400, using a focal length around 93mm for tight shots.
Color Grading: Selectively desaturate skin tones (reds and oranges) to create a silvery-gray aesthetic.
Color Grading: Saturate the yellows and shift the hue slightly towards green to match the specific Pantone color.
Adjust contrast and highlights to accentuate cheekbones and increase drama.
Workflow Tip: Build the lighting setup by starting with the rim lights first to ensure proper placement before turning on the main light.

key_takeaways: Soft light sources are often more flattering on darker skin tones to smooth out texture.
Grids on softboxes are essential for controlling lens flare and light spill when using colored gels.
A dramatic color grade can be achieved by desaturating skin tones while hyper-saturating the wardrobe color.
When building a multi-light setup, start with the back/rim lights to clearly see their effect without the main light washing them out.
